game.name: 1062 - Jelly Boy 2 (Japan) (Proto)
game.info: KingMike presents a 100% complete translation of Jelly Boy 2. It is available in both IPS and NINJA patch format. KingMike notes that this ROM WILL have a bad checksum, since it’s a prototype game. Patch with the NINJA version and it’s impossible to patch the wrong ROM.

game.name: 1063 - Actraiser (Japan)
game.info: Shame on you if you’ve never played Actraiser before! This version, other than having an amazingly badass logo, is actually a lot harder than the US release of the game. Even in Fillmore 1, there are more brambles, more monsters, more everything. It’s crazy great. Ian Kelley wanted to retranslate the game, so here it is! Far be it from me to deprive one of my star translators from an awesome request or two!

game.name: 1070 - Tales of Phantasia (Japan)
game.info: Here is a Dutch translation for the SNES ROM, Tales of Phantasia. Please use a clean ROM with a Header added to it.

game.name: 1086 - Chibi Maruko-chan - Harikiri 365-nichi no Maki (Japan)
game.info: It’s complete except for the menus, which are compressed. There are, however, instructions of how the menus work in the readme.

game.name: 1105 - Snoopy Concert (Japan)
game.info: Snoopy Concert is less a game and more a collection of four smaller ones. Snoopy (of Peanuts fame, yes that Snoopy) is preparing to give a concert to the Peanuts gang, but so far, Marcie and Patty are the only ones who’ve shown up. Snoopy (and occasionally Woodstock) must then help solve the gang’s various problems - with each character having a distinctly different minigame to play. Rerun’s segment is a stroller chase, Schroeder’s is a standard point-and-click style abstract adventure game, Linus’s is a bit of a reflex test and Charlie Brown’s is a trading game.

game.name: 1111 - Final Fantasy III (USA)

game.name: 1172 - Final Fantasy - Mystic Quest (USA)
game.info: This project came along when taarna32 and I were discussing games that need a good re-translation, and she brought up FF:MQ. She told me that tons of the names were translated incorrectly (giving me “Tristam” as an example, whose name is “Lock”, y’know, he’s a treasure hunter, picks locks, get it?). So thus, I took up the project.

The resulting new patch translates everything Gaijin’s did, as well as all of the remaining compressed graphics including title logo, world names, menus and mini game text. A new ending has also been created which appears after you beat Amon.

game.name: 1215 - Metal Max Returns (Japan)
game.info: Metal Max is an open, nonlinear RPG with a heavy focus on sidequests and tank tweaking. The main game has you chasing bounty heads and finding new vehicles for your entourage, but there’s so much other stuff to do! You can pimp your tanks with decals and accessories, you can buy furniture and wall hangings for your home, play with little critters that eat your money and grow to enormous proportions, or enjoy a host of minigames. Go hunting for this week’s target and become a rich and famous bounty hunter!

game.name: 1379 - Tenchi Muyou! - Game Hen (Japan)
game.info: The Tenchi Muyo! English Translation Patch was created in 2000 by Lina`chan, Nuku-Nuku and Filia’s Translations. The patch they released was riddled with bugs and missing some key elements. This game really needed some help, so nine years later, borderLine took it upon himself to address the problems in this addictive Strategy/RPG.

game.name: 1384 - Breath of Fire II (USA)
game.info: This is the long-awaited English version of d4s’ Breath of Fire 2 retranslation/enhancement patch, two-and-a-half years in the making.

game.name: 1429 - Mystic Ark (Japan)
game.info: Mystic Ark, commonly (and improperly) known as “The 7th Saga 2″ in some circles, is an RPG by Enix that spans worlds, and embeds a lot of adventure/puzzle elements into the genre. Disnesquick did the programming for our font, and the text was translated by Ian Kelley. You’ll pardon the brief description, but it’s after midnight, I’ve been working on this game virtually every available moment for the past two weeks, and I’m really, really tired. But the patch is out, so I guess it was worth it. I’m pleased with the result, but it took one hell of a lot of effort to get this far.

game.name: 1441 - Holy Umbrella - Dondera no Mubou!! (Japan)
game.info: Holy Umbrella - Dondera’s Wild!! is a silly action/rpg platformer game! The main character gets transported to an alternate world when he picks up an umbrella, and he has to save it to get home. The game is full of all sorts of cliche plot elements and jokes. It’s a total camp overload, but it’s a still a lot of fun. Script’s been fully translated by the intrepid Hexafire, and has been edited by yours truly. So enjoy!

game.name: 1450 - Super Bomber Man 4 (Japan)

game.name: 1655 - Captain Tsubasa III - Koutei no Chousen (Japan)
game.description: Captain Tsubasa III - Koutei no Chousen (Japan)
game.info: The last game in the Captain Tsubasa series that uses the original game engine. Many consider this the best game in the series, I personally prefer it over all even the PS2 installment. The entire game is playable and can be beaten with the help of this patch, the only parts left untranslated are the last few cut scenes in story mode and a few random events that occur during the final games in story mode. I do not know if the ending is translated since I never actually beat the last team. I made this patch in 2009 after two separate translators abandoned the project, they each worked on different parts of the game and without them we would not have this. In Latin America the Captain Tsubasa anime is known as “Super Campeones” (Super Champions). Special thanks to Spectrum XD and Virgo64.

game.name: 278 - Alcahest (Japan)
game.info: Translation’s as good as the readme says it is! There were one or two lines which made me do a double-take and go “huh?” and there were a few of the pixel-erase bugs and stage name bugs that the readme claimed and stuff. There was one bug I didn’t see mentioned in the readme, and that’s that during the ending, a guy (no names, no spoilers) is riding off on a horse, and he goes offscreen, and then the ground continues to scroll and it just… ends. Probably simply a text speed issue or some such, nothing huge ^_^ Overall, the patch is quite solid and quite complete. Have fun!

game.name: 279 - Angelique (Japan)
game.info: Only part of the intro and a few of the responses to some (gibberish) questions are translated.

game.name: 280 - Bahamut Lagoon (Japan)
game.info: As far as I’ve played so far, this is a quality translation. I’d say it even rivals many commercial efforts. Dark Force, Neill, and Tomato should all be congratulated for this effort. In fact, as an assignment, you are all hereby ORDERED to read the readme, as it will give you a true appreciation for everything that went into this translation, maggots. Failure to comply will result in sexecution/s extreme disappointment.

game.name: 2805 - Fire Emblem - Monshou no Nazo (Japan)
game.info: An updated version of the RPGuy translation that updates names to their official European names as of the official Shadow Dragon release.

game.name: 281 - Bahamut Lagoon (Japan)
game.info: This patch translates the (rather short) intro, and that’s pretty much it.

game.name: 283 - Bahamut Lagoon (Japan)
game.info: Now, I realize that this is only a beta… So nobody take any of the following statements to heart:

game.name: 2835 - 3x3 Eyes - Juuma Houkan (Japan)
game.info: This is an complete English translation of 3×3 Eyes for the SNES.

game.name: 2850 - Dossun! Ganseki Battle (Japan)
game.info: Full dialog translation to Spanish, title screen and options not translated, for: “Dossun! Ganseki Battle”, for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System. Based on the translation by Aeon Genesis.

game.name: 288 - Gourmet Sentai Barayarou (Japan)
game.info: Well, most of the in-game stuff is done, like enemies and ingredients, but the story stuff and character bios aren’t. Sorry. It’s not like the plot’s gonna be interesting anyways. Play the game. There’s Moai heads. They sneeze.

game.name: 2881 - Magna Braban - Henreki no Yuusha (Japan)
game.info: This is an alternate font patch for KingMike’s Magna Braban English Translation. Community consensus was the original font in KingMike’s translation was hard to read, so DaMarsMan made this patch to make it easier to read. It was originally a misc external link and has now been grandfathered in as a regular entry.

game.name: 289 - Bastard!! - Ankoku no Hakaishin (Japan)
game.info: This is actually a joint project between DeJap and Anus P. of J2e Translations. Apparently Dark Force has trouble with the game too, because he hacked an instant-kill trainer into the game. See and find it! Yay!

game.name: 2916 - Star Fox 2 (Beta TD) [T+Eng1.00_Aeon Genesis][o1]
game.info: The English translation of AGTP (v1.0) unfortunately has a few problems, which can be solved with these patches in whole or in part.

game.name: 292 - BS Dragon Quest (BS) [h1]
game.info: This patch translates most of the menus and a few items, so it’s at least somewhat playable.

game.name: 297 - Gekitou Burning Pro Wres (Japan)
game.info: A lot of the menus are done. But, not all of them. The wrestlers’ names aren’t changed, presumably because they’re compressed in the ROM, so included with the patch is a save file you can use. When you load the game with the save file, all the wrestler names (save one) are displayed in English.

game.name: 300 - Chou Mahou Tairiku Wozz (Japan)
game.info: All of the 8×8 text (menus etc.) is translated! Well, almost. And that’s about it.

game.name: 301 - Chrono Trigger (USA)
game.info: This patch pretty much alters the 8×8 font to that of the one in Sky Render’s FF6 retranslation, with some other minor work done. I guess the object of this project is to fix the “miserable” job that Square did in the official translation. This is just my opinion, but I feel that this and Final Fantasy VI had perfectly good translations, and most of the discrepancies are very cosmetic, at best.

game.name: 302 - Clock Tower (Japan)
game.info: This a complete English translation patch of the original Clock Tower on Super Famicom.

game.name: 303 - Cu-On-Pa SFC (Japan)
game.info: This is an English translation of Cu-On-Pa SFC for the SNES.

game.name: 307 - Dark Law - Meaning of Death (Japan)
game.info: Gideon Zhi picked this up from Haeleth and completed it. There’s a lot of low level hacking that went into this and it shows. So check it out.

game.name: 3072 - Chrono Trigger (USA)
game.info: This is an updated version of Doctor L’s released translation that fixes many issues and further localizes the text, with the final product hopefully being something closer in quality to an official translation.

game.name: 3074 - Rockman & Forte (Japan)
game.info: Full German translation of Rockman & Forte. Some graphics were hacked, as well as special characters were added to the game.

game.name: 3075 - Mega Man 7 (USA)
game.info: Full German translation of Mega Man VII. Some graphics were hacked, as well as special characters were added to the game.

game.name: 3076 - Mega Man X (USA) (Rev 1)
game.info: Full German translation of Mega Man X.

game.name: 3077 - Mega Man X2 (USA)
game.info: Full German translation of Mega Man X2. Some graphics were hacked, as well as special characters were added to the game.

game.name: 3078 - Mega Man X3 (USA)
game.info: Full German translation of Mega Man X3. Some graphics were hacked, as well as special characters were added to the game.

game.name: 308 - Laplace no Ma (Japan)
game.info: The Laplace’s Demon translation was originally released in 2001. There was a very strong (and ill-conceived) push to get it out on Halloween back then, and the resultant patch was terribly buggy; battle menus didn’t display right, status menus didn’t display right, lots of item names had been chopped down to fit in available space, battle narrative didn’t display in the correct order, and the writing was in desperate need of an edit.

game.name: 309 - Langrisser, Der (Japan)
game.info: As far as I know, this is the final release by Moon Knight. He was releasing them daily at one point, which makes figuring out which is the latest version some two to three years later a bit difficult. Anyways, the Light path is completely translated in this patch. You’ll need a version 1.0 ROM for this translation, as version 1.1 hangs on a black screen.

game.name: 310 - Kaite Tsukutte Asoberu Dezaemon (J) [h1]
game.info: This patch will not run on the GoodSNES verified ROM of Dezaemon (in fact, the [T-Eng] version crashes at the first screen.. way to go Cowering), and requires a bad checksum ROM that is very difficult to find (because, naturally, it isn’t in GoodSNES). Version 1.41 of SNES9x finally fixes Dezaemon’s SRAM issues, so hopefully soon we’ll have a new patch that will be playable on the good ROM.

game.name: 311 - Do-Re-Mi Fantasy - Milon no Dokidoki Daibouken (Japan)
game.description: Do-Re-Mi Fantasy - Milon no Dokidoki Daibouken (Japan)
game.info: For some reason, the Gaijin website has the version 0.98 patch on their site, and not this one. This was put out a few months later and fixes some text bugs.

patch.name: Do-Re-Mi Fantasy - Milon no Dokidoki Daibouken (Japan).ips

rom.name: Do-Re-Mi Fantasy - Milon no Dokidoki Daibouken (Japan).sfc

game.name: 314 - Dossun! Ganseki Battle (Japan)
game.info: Everything’s complete in this patch except the Options screen. So do check it out.

game.name: 319 - Dragon Ball Z - Hyper Dimension (Japan)
game.info: The patch claims to be 100% fully done, but there are still some Japanese artifacts such as names and ki. In any case, the script is apparently done, so it’s definitely fully playable.

game.name: 320 - Dragon Ball Z - Hyper Dimension (Japan)
game.info: A wee bit of this game is done. it translates most of the dialogue between Piccolo, Goku and Freeza, although the formatting and spelling are horrendous. Menus are done, too.

game.name: 324 - Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.description: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: This is the newest patch by Vincent, who used to be the head of DBZ Translations. Then he quit the scene, publicly released his work, and had it practically raped by several different parties. But that’s moot because Vincent is back now, and has finished his work. And it seems much better than DBZ Game Translations’ work. But that’s probably because this patch actually is as complete as it claims to be, displays slightly better grammar, has expanded names, and is a little more faithful to the literal translation. It’s your choice. But if it were mine, I’d go with this patch until Sir Yoink finishes his.

patch.name: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1).ips

rom.name: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1).sfc

game.name: 325 - Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.description: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: This is a translation of the french ROM, and it’s just a continuation of Vincent’s work. Anyway, the patch is supposedly 98% done, but then again, the last two patches were supposedly 100%. But apparently, they weren’t. Either way, they’re not claiming that this one is done, so perhaps they’re not fibbing this time. Either way, you can always download the patch and try for yourself.

patch.name: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1).ips

rom.name: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1).sfc

game.name: 326 - Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.description: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: After a long period of inactivity, this translation is finally finished! Everything in the game is complete, including the intro and endings. Release 1.02 fixes bugs reported in the 2011 complete release. Have fun!

patch.name: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1).ips

rom.name: Dragon Ball Z - Super Saiya Densetsu (Japan) (Rev 1).sfc

game.name: 330 - Dragon Ball Z - Super Butouden (Japan)
game.info: This is an English translation of Dragon Ball Z: Super Butouden for the SNES.

game.name: 334 - Dragon Ball Z - Super Butouden 3 (Japan)
game.info: Everything’s done except the menus. Whether you choose this patch or AGTP’s is simply a matter of eeny-meeny-miney-moe, as they’re pretty much the same in every respect. There’s patches in this ZIP file for both the Japanese and French versions of the game.

game.name: 336 - Dragon Quest I & II (Japan)
game.info: If you play this patch (and honestly, since RPGONE’s translation… why?), be aware that there ARE bugs in this release. For starters, you will not be able to rescue the princess from the dragon in DQ1. Just be aware of this. Honestly, you’re not going to download this anyways.

game.name: 340 - Dragon Quest V - Tenkuu no Hanayome (Japan)
game.description: Dragon Quest V - Tenkuu no Hanayome (Japan)
game.info: Some menus are done, a few monsters, and an item. Not worth a download, kids.

patch.name: Dragon Quest V - Tenkuu no Hanayome (Japan).ips

rom.name: Dragon Quest V - Tenkuu no Hanayome (Japan).sfc

game.name: 341 - Dragon Quest V - Tenkuu no Hanayome (Japan)
game.description: Dragon Quest V - Tenkuu no Hanayome (Japan)
game.info: This is well done and very polished translation. It took three years to complete, and although much of that three years was chalked up while waiting for a small bug to be ironed out, the folks involved didn’t sit idly by. The script was poured over and edited a great deal, resulting in a very loose translation with a lot of character. While it’s not entirely a literal translation, the edits didn’t go the extremes that Working Designs sometimes goes to. Some people will like the looseness, some will not. The choice is yours.

patch.name: Dragon Quest V - Tenkuu no Hanayome (Japan).ips

rom.name: Dragon Quest V - Tenkuu no Hanayome (Japan).sfc

game.name: 343 - Dragon Quest VI - Maboroshi no Daichi (Japan)
game.description: Dragon Quest VI - Maboroshi no Daichi (Japan)
game.info: The DeJap situation with Dragon Quest VI is a bit of a mess - At one point they had four separate released patches, each with different stuff done. This patch here, called Version A on their site, is the furthest along, probably. This has hacking work by Antiriad and Dark Force, with translation by Unafarmer and Hojo. Estimates from the website, which could be wrong, have translation completion at about 40%.

patch.name: Dragon Quest VI - Maboroshi no Daichi (Japan).ips

rom.name: Dragon Quest VI - Maboroshi no Daichi (Japan).sfc

game.name: 344 - Dragon Quest VI - Maboroshi no Daichi (Japan)
game.description: Dragon Quest VI - Maboroshi no Daichi (Japan)
game.info: You may have seen NoPrgress mentioned on DeJap and stuff, but don’t be fooled! This patch right here is entirely his own work. And it looks sweeeeeet! You can play the game from beginning to end; the untranslated 10% is just random strings here and there that have no real bearing on the game. There are some fatal bugs in the game (most notably, backing out of the Info-All option sometimes crashes the game), so if you plan to use this translation (and you should, since it’s currently the furthest along), be sure to keep a batch of savestates at the ready.

patch.name: Dragon Quest VI - Maboroshi no Daichi (Japan).ips

rom.name: Dragon Quest VI - Maboroshi no Daichi (Japan).sfc

game.name: 345 - Dual Orb II (Japan)
game.info: This is a complete English translation for Dual Orb 2. Both IPS and xdelta format patches are included.

game.name: 348 - Feda - The Emblem of Justice (Japan)
game.info: Not much at all is done here, but just about everything you would need in a battle is translated. Still, not worth looking at anymore.

game.name: 349 - Feda - The Emblem of Justice (Japan)
game.info: The background of the English version of Feda is really the story of one man’s efforts that span a number of years, perhaps a decade or more. Along with many people in the 1980s and 90s, Bongo` (his translation community name) became enamored with video games, specifically role playing games (RPGs), and soon discovered that a treasure trove of outstanding Japanese RPGs would never be ported to the western world. Unlike most RPG players, however, Bongo` possessed a unique skill in computer code savvy and program writing, and putting himself in even rarer company, he dedicated those skills to endeavors such as creating an English patch for Feda, his long term signature project.

game.name: 352 - Final Fantasy IV (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: This is an English translation the original Japanese version of Final Fantasy IV for the SNES.

game.name: 353 - Final Fantasy V (Japan)
game.info: RPGe’s FFV translation is probably the most famous fan translation ever. It was the first RPG to ever be completely translated, and a lot of ROM hackers and translators today cite this project as the reason they got into the hobby. Given the project’s troubled history, it’s really nice to see such an overwhelmingly positive result.

game.name: 356 - Fire Emblem - Monshou no Nazo (Japan)
game.info: This patch translates all the dialogue up to Chapter 5. Of course, that means that none of the menus have been so much as touched, which makes playing this game incredibly difficult. I have enough trouble with strategy RPGs as it is! Be sure and use a ROM with no header before patching it. Magic Destiny will be continuing with the work that Taichou and company have done here.

game.name: 363 - Go Go Ackman (Japan)
game.info: The translation comes out really good. It’s interesting to see the humor being translated into English and still be effective.

game.name: 366 - Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan)
game.description: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan)
game.info: This patch makes the game just barely playable in english, though none of the story/dialog is translated yet.

patch.name: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan).ips

rom.name: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan).sfc

game.name: 367 - Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan)
game.description: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan)
game.info: Once, a long time ago, maht of RPGe was hacking and translating this game. Then he gave up on it, and RPGe disappeared. So la.

patch.name: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan).ips

rom.name: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan).sfc

game.name: 368 - Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan)
game.description: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan)
game.info: No, this isn’t anywhere near complete. Yes, Kikuyama is Swedish. No, English isn’t his first language. Yes, this patch is full of bugs. No, it’s not that good at all.

patch.name: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan).ips

rom.name: Hanjuku Hero - Ah, Sekai yo Hanjuku Nare...!! (Japan).sfc

game.name: 372 - Jerry Boy (Japan)
game.info: This is Chris Covell’s first translation project, and it turned out pretty well I think. There were a couple of graphic bugs in the original game that he fixed as well.

game.name: 373 - Jutei Senki (Japan)
game.info: There’s two patches in here, use JUTEI-I.IPS if your ROM is interleaved, and JUTEI.IPS if it is not. Those SMC.COM-savvy users can tell which is which by looking under “Format”.

game.name: 374 - Kidou Butouden G Gundam (Japan)
game.info: Gideon took this game on as an exercise in changing font widths, and as this patch demonstrates, he was successful. The translation for the story mode text was handled quite well by Alexander Beetle, and should be an enjoyable read. Unfortunately, if you made it this far down the page, you’ve already read my game review, and know that is a really horrible game. So, you may never see those keen translations.

game.name: 375 - Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan)
game.description: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan)
game.info: Ipkiss won’t really comment on this, except to say that hacking it sucks. Playing the game, I notice that there’s some english, and a ball gets thrown around as players get with the ball, and other things. It’s Kunio, so you better believe there’s violence involved. This project is also dead because Ipkiss hated hacking it.

patch.name: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan).ips

rom.name: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan).sfc

game.name: 377 - Little Magic (Japan)
game.info: It has been reported by odino, using a password to get to the end, that this game is in fact 100% translated and complete. Enjoy!

game.name: 379 - Live A Live (Japan)
game.info: This translates a few random words. Not worth a look. Make sure your ROM’s deinterleaved.

game.name: 381 - Live A Live (Japan)
game.info: We have all of the issues worked out (we hope!) It’s gone through a few rigorous testing cycles, which continue even as I write this. The end result is a patch that blows everything else out of the water. This is very likely Aeon Genesis’s definitive work, exceeding possibly even Rudra in its grandeur.

game.name: 386 - Madou Monogatari - Hanamaru Daiyouchienji (Japan)
game.info: J2e’s necrosaro was working on this, but I guess passed it off to Gideon Zhi to finish. And now Gideon Zhi’s done with it. Love them. The current version fixes some bugs that appeared in version 1.0.

game.name: 387 - Magic Knight Rayearth (Japan)
game.info: Note the file MKRHARD.IPS in the zip file. This modifies the way that HP is gained when you go up a level. I haven’t tried it myself, but I assume that the only thing that changes is the game’s difficulty.

game.name: 388 - Magna Braban - Henreki no Yuusha (Japan)
game.info: This is the completed 2.0 release of KingMike’s Magna Braban English Translation. The 2.0 patch uses the same translation as the 1.0, but the hacking has been redone and should be compatible with more accurate emulators.

game.name: 389 - Majin Tensei (Japan)
game.info: Here is a really old patch created back in 2000 for Majin Tensei which translates a few things here and there. This will not be updated anymore than it is and will be removed once Aeon Genesis releases their complete version of their patch for the game. Please do not contact the author for support on this patch or ask to continue and finish this project as it is dead. On a brief testing of the patch, it seems to work on all versions of the ROM without a header. Use at your own risk.

game.name: 391 - Miracle Girls (Japan)
game.info: Hmm, this is a SEKRIT PATCH that SGST released, hidden cleverly in their HTML. But … I don’t see what it translates. Maybe I didn’t play far enough.

game.name: 392 - Monstania (Japan)
game.info: This is a superb translation of a superb game, and it comes highly recommended. And as an added bonus, the current patch is compatible with the correct-size ROM (20 mbit). The bad dump (24 mbit) is no longer supported.

game.name: 394 - Mystic Ark (Japan)
game.info: A patch from a long long time ago. I remember when they were still alive. Bleh, I’ve been in this stupid “scene” far too long. Anyways, this patch translates most of the menus, and a few spells.

game.name: 396 - Mystic Ark (Japan)
game.info: The page for Mystic Ark that used to be at Transcore never got updated, and when the site reopened in January, the page was mysteriously gone. I’d say that the translation is dead, hm? This patch translates (and expands!) most of the menus, and also translates a few sentences from the intro.

game.name: 398 - Neugier - Umi to Kaze no Kodou (Japan)
game.description: Neugier - Umi to Kaze no Kodou (Japan)
game.info: After 4 years of work, a collaborative effort by Haeleth + RPGOne resulted in complete English translation for Neugier. This translations comes equipped with a nice VWF, fully uncut script, and NINJA and IPS format patches.

patch.name: Neugier - Umi to Kaze no Kodou (Japan).ips

rom.name: Neugier - Umi to Kaze no Kodou (Japan).sfc

game.name: 399 - Panic in Nakayoshi World (Japan)
game.info: Everything is fully englishedized, even if the script is a little strange at times. So there.

game.name: 400 - Nangoku Shounen Papuwa-kun (Japan)
game.info: THIS GAME RULES. Play it. Okay, now the important stuff. Lots of stuff has been done, and lots of stuff hasn’t, such as the opening and any graphical text. And the credits, but I’ll be damned if I can get that far. I suck at this game. Anyway, hopefully F.H. can tidy up the rest of it, because, well, the game rules. Thanks to Karin Aoi, Unicorn23/Rom, David Mullen, Dark Force, and F.H. for a translation I’ve been eagerly expecting for a long long time. Hurray!

game.name: 405 - Lodoss-tou Senki (Japan)
game.info: It looks like nothing but the dialogue has been translated so far, cause the menus haven’t been touched. The readme says items and spells are done, but the few items I looked at didn’t look that way to me. The dialogue isn’t at 100% yet either, so if you see a character saying a bunch of white boxes, you’ll know that isn’t really what they’re saying. Lina`chan has disappeared, so this project is pretty much dead.

game.name: 406 - Rockman & Forte (Japan)
game.info: Everything is translated except for the graphics (compressed) and the CD database (no space). It’s pretty identical to the YnT patch except for the fact that this uses the American, Megaman names.

game.name: 407 - Rockman & Forte (Japan)
game.info: Everything’s done except for the graphics and the CD Database. AGTP’s patch fixes those however, so there’s no longer really any reason to play this patch. Sorry guys.

game.name: 409 - Romancing Sa-Ga (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: From what little I played (so I didn’t play it very long, give me a damn break already), the character creation process is completely done, and so are most of the menus. A few items and spells here and there are also done.

game.name: 410 - Romancing Sa-Ga (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: This is the group that David Mullen was working with before they fell apart due to miscommunication and whatnot. Maybe F.H. was helping out, I don’t remember. Anyways, they’re doing their thing solo now, without the help of Shujin-Rik and friends.

game.name: 411 - Romancing Sa-Ga 2 (Japan)
game.info: It’s not often you see a patch from waaaay back in 1997. Fortunately, it’s a somewhat decent translation, for the most part. Menus are done, as is the intro, and the dialogue (what little there is) up to the first cave. It’s nice to use if you just want to see what the game’s like I guess, though Gilhide’s patch surpasses this one in pretty much everything.

game.name: 412 - Romancing Sa-Ga 2 (Japan)
game.info: From what I played, almost everything menu, monster, and name-related is done. A small bit of the dialogue is done, but it looks like Gilhide was having problems with the game’s variable-width font. It’s not too distracting, though.

game.name: 415 - Romancing Sa-Ga 3 (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: Well, this is actually quite a decent translation. I played it for about half an hour, and only saw a few untranslated stuff, mostly item-related. It’s quite decent, if you can overlook a few obvious misspellings (daeth?). I wouldn’t bother with it over Mana Sword’s patch, though.

game.name: 416 - Romancing Sa-Ga 3 (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: Go with this patch, of course, since it’s mostly finished. While the script could admittedly use some work, and there’s some odd-looking spacing problems (due to the fact that every single tile is two 8×16 characters smooshed onto one 16×16 tile), really, does it matter ithat/i much? No it does not. The translation’s not entirely complete though, and I doubt the little problems that keep it from 100% will ever be fixed up. But like I said, they’re just small details. You’ll live.

game.name: 422 - RPG Tsukuru - Super Dante (Japan)
game.info: Lots has been translated, which makes the game kind of semi-playable, but this is one of those games you really need to be completely in English. It also falls victim to the age-old “there isn’t enough space in these damned menus” problem, so expect a lot of weird abbreviations and whatnot.

game.name: 431 - Rudra no Hihou (Japan)
game.info: Hmm.. The history here seems hard to explain, but this translation first started as part of Transrelic, then some of its members moved to Square Translations. I think. Feel free to correct me. Anyway, all that’s finished right now is the menus.

game.name: 435 - Bishoujo Senshi Sailor Moon R (Japan)
game.info: Even though most Brawlers aren’t very text heavy, what’s translated in this patch is very good. All the text formatting behaves like it should, and no engrish was witnessed in playing the patch. This last fact alone makes it better than 98% of SNK’s official translations.

game.name: 437 - Sanrio World Smash Ball! (Japan)
game.info: The game is completely finished! And look at that font! LordTech seriously rocks, you guys.

game.name: 438 - SD Gundam G Next (Japan)
game.info: This is a very old patch from 2001, and the project has been abandoned for many years now. Serin9x is no longer working on translations.

game.name: 439 - Super Gachapon World - SD Gundam X (Japan)
game.description: Super Gachapon World - SD Gundam X (Japan)
game.info: Everything’s finished, aside from some graphical text. I’d say it wasn’t a big deal, but I don’t know what it says, so maybe it’s trying to tell me something important. Who can say!

patch.name: Super Gachapon World - SD Gundam X (Japan).ips

rom.name: Super Gachapon World - SD Gundam X (Japan).sfc

game.name: 440 - Seiken Densetsu 3 (Japan)
game.info: Some call it “the best Super Famicom game ever”, some dismiss it as just another boring action game. But most people agree that Square made a grave mistake when they decided not to market Seiken Densetsu 3 overseas - especially after the success of its predecessor, Secret of Mana.

game.name: 452 - Star Ocean (Japan)
game.info: Much, much better than the last patch, this is for all intents and purposes a complete translation. However, there are a few things missing (Yes/No balloons, elemental icons) and as such it’s not yet a truly “Complete” translation. Another patch should be out in the future that resolves all these issues.

game.name: 462 - Super Fire Pro Wrestling X Premium (Japan)
game.description: Super Fire Pro Wrestling X Premium (Japan)
game.info: Almost everything is finished in this patch, with what’s not done being pretty damned inconsequential. There’s a whole hell of a lot of abbreviations going on here, but that couldn’t be helped I guess.

patch.name: Super Fire Pro Wrestling X Premium (Japan).ips

rom.name: Super Fire Pro Wrestling X Premium (Japan).sfc

game.name: 463 - Shodai Nekketsu Kouha Kunio-kun (Japan)
game.info: There originally wasn’t enough room in the ROM for the English script, so Laxidman just decided to make two patches: one for the first half of the game, and one for the second! It’s kind of ingenious, but also frustrating for the end-user. Fortunately, Laxidman went back and released this all-in-one patch with some additional fixes.

game.name: 466 - Dai-3-ji Super Robot Taisen (Japan)
game.info: Everything’s complete, except for (of course) a few tiny bugs. Play the game!

game.name: 467 - Dai-4-ji Super Robot Taisen (Japan)
game.info: SadNES cITy was a group that did Italian translations. You’d think that this would make the dialogue in this patch sound stilted, but there’s no dialogue translated so it doesn’t really matter much. You can check the full list in the readme, but it’s all just stuff like menus and items and attacks and whatnot.

game.name: 468 - Super Robot Taisen Gaiden - Masoukishin - The Lord of Elemental (Japan)
game.description: Super Robot Taisen Gaiden - Masoukishin - The Lord of Elemental (Japan)
game.info: This patch only translates stuff like chapter names, character names, mecha names, weapons, and the opening scene (including the priceless line shown below). And the font looks really funky.

patch.name: Super Robot Taisen Gaiden - Masoukishin - The Lord of Elemental (Japan).ips

rom.name: Super Robot Taisen Gaiden - Masoukishin - The Lord of Elemental (Japan).sfc

game.name: 470 - Tales of Phantasia (Japan)
game.info: If you’re one of those lame kiddies who think that graphics make a good RPG, well you’re going to like Tales of Phantasia. If you’re everybody else, and you know that gameplay is also important to a good RPG, well you’re going to like Tales of Phantasia. This is one of the games developed by the god-company tri-Ace, back when they still worked for Namco and stuff. They’re the same folks who made Star Ocean and Valkyrie Profile, and the same things that made those games badass are at work in this one: awesome graphics, and a kickass game to back it up, with a different and innovative combat system. If you can’t tell, I like this game a lot. Describing the battle system is difficult.. I’ve frequently heard it referred to as sort of a fighting game, but that’s completely wrong. It allows for a lot more strategy and movement than most games, but you really have to see it for yourself. A is to attack, B is to use a special technique, Y is to change your targeting, and X brings up the menu. Sure, the AI’s dumber than a rock, and it’s annoying when you’re trying to fight a Harpy and you’re just standing there slashing at air, but it’s more fun than you’re likely to have from doing something else. And that’s what’s important.

game.name: 471 - Tales of Phantasia (Japan)
game.info: This is Disnesquick’s patch for the infinitely popular Tales of Phantasia. For those of you who have been living in a bubble, this game is a fantastic RPG, one that would seem its up there with the greats, like Final Fantasy. It employs a new battle system, where the battles are a side view like a platformer. It adds some more strategy, but also some frustration when dealing with flying enemies. Overall, its not too bad. This game definitely warrants attention from anyone who hasn’t played. Disnesquick’s patch here is an alpha patch, and you must also have an INTERLEAVED rom. I’m sure that this release is getting a bit blown over, since Dejap just released their final patch for the game. Of course, for all of you die hard fans, should definitely take a look at this one too.

game.name: 473 - Tales of Phantasia (Japan)
game.info: There is not much that I can see as being translated in this patch. Which is strange, because if I’m reading the readme correctly, it was based off CyBeRGoth’s work. Strange, indeed. And I think Disnesquick was involved in this project at one point, as his name made a few of the updates on the Trans-tech page. Anyhow, this patch isn’t very good compared to Dejap’s, or even Disnesquick’s. I really only have it on here for archival purposes.

game.name: 480 - Torneko no Daibouken - Fushigi no Dungeon (Japan)
game.description: Torneko no Daibouken - Fushigi no Dungeon (Japan)
game.info: If you are having patching problems, make sure your ROM is version 1.0, and that is has a header. The lovely Tush utility will tell you both of those things. Look for “Header: Exist” and “Version: 1.0″.

patch.name: Torneko no Daibouken - Fushigi no Dungeon (Japan).ips

rom.name: Torneko no Daibouken - Fushigi no Dungeon (Japan).sfc

game.name: 481 - Tenchi Muyou! - Game Hen (Japan)
game.info: Version 0.98 of this translation has quite a few bugs, such as text going outside the text window, battle text bugs, and a basic lack of status screen. Hopefully these will be fixed later, but there’s no definitive word on it. The game, however, is fully translated, which makes it officially “complete.”

game.name: 483 - Fushigi no Dungeon 2 - Fuurai no Shiren (Japan)
game.description: Fushigi no Dungeon 2 - Fuurai no Shiren (Japan)
game.info: Here is what Gideon Zhi himself had to say about this patch:

patch.name: Fushigi no Dungeon 2 - Fuurai no Shiren (Japan).ips

rom.name: Fushigi no Dungeon 2 - Fuurai no Shiren (Japan).sfc

game.name: 484 - Hameln no Violin Hiki (Japan)
game.info: Oh my god, this game rules. Despite the fact that Hamel looks… shall we say… less than intimidating when he plays his violin at enemies, this game rules. It plays sorta like what would happen if Ys 3 and Milon’s Secret Castle got drunk one night and… well, you get the picture. You play as this violinist guy who goes around playing music a lot. And you get this tag-along girl named Flute who you can chuck at enemies. But that’s not all! If you collect costumes, she can morph into nifty other weird creature things that usually look rather demented, and she’s invincible and has special powers. But she also tends to go off and do her own thing, and disappears RIGHT when you need her. So the costumes can be a bad thing too. But the game rules nonetheless. GO PLAY. NOW.

game.name: 490 - Treasure Hunter G (Japan)
game.info: This new patch includes some new fonts and fixes a bug that happened at Herman’s Cave if you read the Notebook for the first time at the door. Some names have also been reworked. But seeing that Metalhawk hasn’t tested the patch properly, he still considers it incomplete.

game.name: 491 - Treasure Hunter G (Japan)
game.info: Why did this get canceled? I don’t really know. But I’m pretty sure it did, since this patch is from 1997 and Knight4J quit emulation a while ago. I’m not even sure that this is their final patch; I think I just found this on the Emucamp FTP, or at Zophar’s or something. Anyway be sure and email me if you know about this patch or whatever. This translates most of the battle tutorial that that old guy gives you, and a few other sentences. :) Most of it’s in Japanese though.

game.name: 493 - Umihara Kawase (Japan)
game.info: Well the only thing that was in Japanese was the Replay menus, so those are all translated and happy. So things are groovy, and all is happy. Yep.

game.name: 495 - Wedding Peach (Japan)
game.info: Hmm! Well the page isn’t there anymore, so, erm, I guess it’s dead, or something. Which is not all a bad thing, if you’ve seen this patch. :) Not only does the game suck (at least in my opinion, of course), this is probably the worst translation I’ve ever seen. I can understand if there wasn’t enough space to say everything, but it’s actually kind of ridiculous to hear “…WAS GOOD BEST IS BANANA” you know? Well anyway, the rom used to be included in the zip, but has been removed from this one due to the No Roms Policy on Parodius.com. Our sincere apologies. Find the rom yourself.

game.name: 496 - Wizardry I-II-III - Story of Llylgamyn (Japan) (En,Ja) (NP)
game.info: Rock on! Wizardry is neat little first-person dungeon crawler that first appeared on the Apple ][. It has a very Dungeons & Dragons feel to it, which comes from the basic game play system, and the general “ambiance” of the game.

game.name: 497 - Wonder Project J - Kikai no Shounen Pino (Japan)
game.description: Wonder Project J - Kikai no Shounen Pino (Japan)
game.info: This is a really cool game from Enix, evil programmers extraordinaire. You are the human controller for a robot whose creator was kidnapped. Your commands, issued via an interface unit that looks rather like a fairy, are carried out by the robot. If he feels like it. Your other job is to condition him into doing the actions you want him to. For instance, if he walks over to a book and throws it like a baseball, you gotta slap him upside his head. If he reads it, you have to praise him. Simple enough, huh? Wrong. If he gets scolded too many times, he’ll stop listening to you. Period. And except for when the robot misbehaves too many times in a row, this is a damn fun game. And hey, if you didn’t catch it before, it’s Enix. You’re obliged to play it. So stop reading and make with the playing.

patch.name: Wonder Project J - Kikai no Shounen Pino (Japan).ips

rom.name: Wonder Project J - Kikai no Shounen Pino (Japan).sfc

game.name: 527 - Magical Drop (Japan)
game.info: It seems that everything is translated in this, which must not have been a super-duper feat since the only text is the menus and the intro. :-)

game.name: 528 - Front Mission Series - Gun Hazard (Japan)
game.info: Check the readme for known bugs and stuff. Specifically, sometimes when writing text to the screen, the game leaves out a letter. It’s really weird, but Gideon Zhi already knows about it and it’s not a big deal, I guess.

game.name: 542 - Langrisser, Der (Japan)
game.info: The grammar is horrible, things are spelled incorrectly, the script can’t seem to agree with itself on character and location names…yadayada. Of course, this was released on April 1 2002, so take it as you will. It’s a lash out at all the people who tell translation groups to just “babelfish it.”

game.name: 550 - Final Fantasy IV - Easy Type (Japan)
game.info: This is the first alpha version of Dragonsbrethren’s Final Fantasy IV Easy Type translation. Consider it a replacement for the old version released back in October of 2002. It features accurate translation of item, enemy, and skill names (barring exceptions made for commonly localized terms and things that simply wouldn’t fit) and a fully translated main menu. It should be far more playable than his previous translation.

game.name: 568 - Battle Soccer - Field no Hasha (Japan)
game.info: There’s screens that come up before every match that say what world you’re playing in, which are still in Japanese. Other than that, everything is translated. The font could be better though, but hey.

game.name: 570 - Shin Kidou Senki Gundam W - Endless Duel (Japan)
game.description: Shin Kidou Senki Gundam W - Endless Duel (Japan)
game.info: Well, there wasn’t much to do, besides menus, post-fight banter and intro/ending text, and of course having been a project of THE ZHI, all that stuff is done. Play this game without fear of random Japanese phrases!

patch.name: Shin Kidou Senki Gundam W - Endless Duel (Japan).ips

rom.name: Shin Kidou Senki Gundam W - Endless Duel (Japan).sfc

game.name: 571 - Shin Megami Tensei (Japan)
game.info: A lot of people seem to have trouble patching the game. It’s really easy guys, just make sure you use the version 1.0 ROM, and that the ROM has a header. Okay? If you don’t know how to check those, get SMC.COM from the FAQ page.

game.name: 598 - Shin Nekketsu Kouha - Kunio-tachi no Banka (Japan)
game.description: Shin Nekketsu Kouha - Kunio-tachi no Banka (Japan)
game.info: What’s to say? This is the work of Gideon, and it should go without saying that everything is translated with no errors or glitches that I encountered. The language of the script is a little coarse, but given that it’s a Kunio game, it’s probably coarse in the Japanese version as well. Anyhow, another job well-done by Gideon.

patch.name: Shin Nekketsu Kouha - Kunio-tachi no Banka (Japan).ips

rom.name: Shin Nekketsu Kouha - Kunio-tachi no Banka (Japan).sfc

game.name: 612 - Fire Emblem - Monshou no Nazo (Japan) (Rev 1)
game.info: This will only work on a ROM that is Version 1.1.

game.name: 621 - Rockman & Forte (Japan)
game.info: Aside from a minor graphic, everything is translated and very enjoyable. Fixing this graphic isn’t really an issue, it’s just that satsu is L-A-Z-Y. So la.

game.name: 622 - Ganpuru - Gunman's Proof (Japan)
game.info: This is one of the few translated scripts to have been graced by the editing hand of Shih Tzu, and the end result is absolutely gorgeous. Regardless of your feelings towards the game itself, the translation is nothing short of remarkable. Oh, Gideon Zhi and Zackman did a good job too. Definitely.

game.name: 624 - Fire Emblem - Thracia 776 (Japan)
game.info: About 90% of the menus are done. The font’s kinda rough, but it looks pretty cool. That pretty much goes for the entire translation, actually.

game.name: 649 - Majuu Ou (Japan)
game.info: The translation is really good, with no errors and good grammar. The new title screen is nice as well.

game.name: 660 - Magical Pop'n (Japan)
game.info: Everything’s complete. Isn’t that font awesome? Yeah it is.

game.name: 669 - Rudra no Hihou (Japan)
game.info: The 2.0 version polishes up and improves many things over the original release including a rewritten script, new VWF, polished intro hack, and more. Nice effort put forth by Gideon and AGTP. If you haven’t played Rudra yet, this patch is surely recommended. Even if you have played it, it might be good for a second time through with this much improved patch!

game.name: 687 - Shin Megami Tensei II (Japan)
game.info: Fortunately, SMT2 has gone through some extensive beta testing, and all that’s left are some inconsequential bugs. Check the readme for specifics.

game.name: 688 - Ace o Nerae! (Japan)
game.info: This is a complete English translation of Ace wo Nerae! for the Super Nintendo.

game.name: 689 - Chou Mahou Tairiku Wozz (Japan)
game.info: As always Nightcrawler keeps his promises and brings us the full release of Choumahou Tairiku WOZZ. Both IPS and xdelta format patches are provided.

game.name: 690 - Emerald Dragon (Japan)
game.info: This is a complete English translation for Emerald Dragon. Both IPS and xdelta format patches are included.

game.name: 701 - Daikaijuu Monogatari (Japan)
game.info: Most of the menus, and a few items are done.

game.name: 711 - Feda - The Emblem of Justice (Japan)
game.info: Some 8×8 text is done. Not really worth a look at this point. At all.

game.name: 712 - Chrono Trigger - Music Library (BS)
game.info: This was actually translated to French by Terminus about seven months ago, but Neo Mithrandil had some requests for an English version, so here it is! Isn’t that super neat?

game.name: 715 - Rudra no Hihou (Japan)
game.info: Anus P. has been working on a Rudra translation for years now, or at least had until he went off to Singapore and disappeared. He’s released a sample patch to demonstrate his hacking work on the game, which is admittedly pretty impressive in a lot of areas. This patch uses the dialogue script from AGTP’s translation (which was in turn translated from Terminus’s translation), and wasn’t reformatted for the new variable-width font in any way, so expect to see some funky line formatting and such. In any case, this release still has a few bugs in it and should not be considered “complete” by any means.

game.name: 718 - Accele Brid (Japan)
game.info: Well, Gideon has done well in that everything is translated. However, this isn’t really a text-heavy game, so it’s no surprise that it was finished in a month. This game was basically just a training exercise for Super Robot Wars 3, anyhow.

game.name: 725 - Ranma 1-2 - Akanekodan Teki Hihou (Japan)
game.info: This translates menus and equipment, as well as about ten minutes of (horrible) dialogue. 16×16 dialogue. Sexy sexy!

game.name: 758 - Cyborg 009 (Japan)
game.info: Apparently savestates don’t work with this translation? Other than that, yay.

game.name: 761 - Eien no Filerna (Japan)
game.info: A fair amount of progress has been made since the last patch release. It’s now near to completion.

game.name: 775 - Juusou Kihei Valken (Japan)
game.info: This is an English translation of Assault Suits Valken for the Super Nintendo.

game.name: 781 - Miracle Girls (Japan)
game.info: This is a complete English translation of Miracle Girls for the Super Nintendo.

game.name: 792 - Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan)
game.description: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan)
game.info: This project was built off of the ipkiss’s old ev0lutions patch. Although, not much has been done yet to set it apart, aside from a hacked title screen. Apparently things like names and attacks are stored separately, and they will be (presumably) dealt with later.

patch.name: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan).ips

rom.name: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan).sfc

game.name: 815 - Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan)
game.description: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan)
game.info: I used to hate this game… because I never managed to find a way to get into a match. I used to go through menu screen after menu screen, not being able to figure out how to beat up people.

patch.name: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan).ips

rom.name: Kunio-kun no Dodge Ball Da yo Zenin Shuugou! (Japan).sfc

game.name: 823 - Heracles no Eikou IV - Kamigami kara no Okurimono (Japan)
game.description: Heracles no Eikou IV - Kamigami kara no Okurimono (Japan)
game.info: Nightcrawler’s Translation Corporation has released this 100% complete English translation. The script translation was done by nanashi whom also did the translation for Glory of Heracles III.

patch.name: Heracles no Eikou IV - Kamigami kara no Okurimono (Japan).ips

rom.name: Heracles no Eikou IV - Kamigami kara no Okurimono (Japan).sfc

game.name: 829 - Star Fox 2 (Beta TD)
game.info: Wow! Everything looks very slick and professional. satsu’s translation fits the tone of the game quite nicely, and the reprogramming work by Gideon Zhi, d4s, and Fusoya betrays no hint of the apparent difficulty in working with a Super FX game. And check out that new title screen!

game.name: 830 - Kidou Senshi Gundam - Cross Dimension 0079 (Japan)
game.info: There seem to be no issues so far. The game’s script was translated by vampiresquid, and the title screen was done by yours truly. It’s difficult to read the dialogue at times, but it’s the programmer’s fault, not Gideon’s.

game.name: 831 - BS Super Mario USA - Power Challenge - Dai-1-kai (BS)
game.description: BS Super Mario USA - Power Challenge - Dai-1-kai (BS)
game.info: This patch translates what little text that shows up on the games, which is when you can change the control scheme or when you check the status in-between levels. The patch was originally tested to work on BS Mario 1 by KingMike, but I’ve tested it on all four roms and it works perfectly.

patch.name: BS Super Mario USA - Power Challenge - Dai-1-kai (BS).ips

rom.name: BS Super Mario USA - Power Challenge - Dai-1-kai (BS).smc

game.name: 852 - Kouryuu no Mimi (Japan)
game.info: This is an English translation of Kouryuu no Mimi for the Super Nintendo.

game.name: 853 - Super Gussun Oyoyo 2 (Japan)
game.info: Complete and looking good! Everything is translated except for a few background images of unimportance - read the readme for details.

game.name: 860 - Dream Maze - Kigurumi Daibouken (Japan)
game.info: Well, the translation is finished, but it still has a few bugs. The hacking in this game is amazing, just as the rest of KingMike’s works. And check out that pretty dialogue font!

game.name: 865 - Fire Emblem - Seisen no Keifu (Japan)
game.info: This project is an attempt to take Jay’s Fire Emblem translation and make it actually playable. It looks great, though it’s difficult to tell from the site exactly what is finished and what is not.

game.name: 881 - Fire Emblem - Thracia 776 (Japan)
game.info: The hacking work done on the game so far looks very professional, what with a pretty font and no apparent glitches. The translation has been handled pretty well, and I think I only noticed one typo in the script. However, the script does need a just a little bit of work; it feels quite close to the original Japanese at times, and a bit of editing to make the English more natural could make this patch really shine.

game.name: 893 - Shodai Nekketsu Kouha Kunio-kun (Japan)
game.info: Shodai Nekketsu Kouha is often misnomered as River City Ransom 2, but that´s not quite right. Kunio and Riki actually gain experience, RPG-style, as well as equip weapons and use items that their enemies drop, learning new moves and special skills, but there´s no money - so you can´t buy anything. That said, there´s a day/night cycle implemented into the game, and certain places are only open at certain times of the day. You can also play some minigames to earn some extra items!

game.name: 900 - Kidou Senshi V Gundam (Japan)
game.info: This one looks to be finally complete with some nice hacking work from RedComet. Enjoy some 100% complete V Gundam action.

game.name: 907 - Hiouden - Mamono-tachi to no Chikai (Japan)
game.info: The translation’s complete, so get cracking! And read the readme, the patch isn’t perfect and the game still has some bugs (which were already in the untranslated game).

game.name: 910 - Cyber Knight II - Chikyuu Teikoku no Yabou (Japan)
game.description: Cyber Knight II - Chikyuu Teikoku no Yabou (Japan)
game.info: Gideon Zhi did a marvelous job with this game. Along with Deuce, who translated the game, as well as z80gaiden and his mysterious friend who supplied compression tools for it, he finished this whole project in under two months! The patch is absolutely on par with any commercially released translation as it features a good looking VWF, multi-line item names and the complete script is even fully recompressed. Moreover the translation is great and very polished. I did not encounter a single piece of Japanese text in the entire game.

patch.name: Cyber Knight II - Chikyuu Teikoku no Yabou (Japan).ips

rom.name: Cyber Knight II - Chikyuu Teikoku no Yabou (Japan).sfc

game.name: 954 - Tales of Phantasia (Japan)
game.info: This is the patch (release r.410) that translate Tales of Phantasia (SNES version) from the Japanese to Italian language. The current revision number is: r.410. A read-me is included with the patch .zip in Microsoft Word .doc format.

game.name: 961 - Fire Emblem - Monshou no Nazo (Japan)
game.info: A mostly complete patch for Fire Emblem: Mystery of the Emblem.

game.name: 973 - Final Fantasy V (Japan)
game.info: Everything should be translated into Swedish. Remember to patch the Japanese ROM.

game.name: 974 - Monstania (Japan)
game.info: Here is a Swedish translation for the SNES title, Monstania. There is only a minor pointer issue that was never fixed, other than that it is 100% complete.

game.name: 975 - Tales of Phantasia (Japan)
game.info: There might be some spelling errors and what not, but it should be fine. Use this patch on the deinterleaved rom.

game.name: 982 - Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.description: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA)
game.info: There are some graphics and text issues, nothing in the dialogues though. It is 100% playable.

patch.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).ips

rom.name: Legend of Zelda, The - A Link to the Past (USA).sfc

game.name: 985 - Terranigma (Europe)
game.info: Only some minor stuff is not translated (Push Start Button, some signs, etc).

game.name: 992 - Skyblazer (USA)
game.info: Here is a Swedish translation for the SNES title, Skyblazer. There might be some untranslated text. Make your sure clean ROM has a header before applying!

game.name: 995 - Alien 3 (USA)
game.info: The only thing that is not translated is the text in the beginning of each stage and the “Game Over” text.

game.name: 996 - Theme Park (Europe) (En,Fr,De)
game.info: Here is a Swedish translation for the SNES title, Theme Park. This patch must be applied to the European ROM with a header.
